doc.title: Basic usage
doc.para:
compile You can compile with Borland C++ 5.5 or later (C++ Builder 5 or later).
Compilation requires regex++ from boost.org.
After installing regex++, compile each cpp file.
In the case of C++ Builder, it is OK just to add to all projects each cpp file of tjs2.
You can compile even gcc 3 or later (you can compile even 2.95 but must be related fixes wstring).

dl.dd: Loading the header files needed to use the TJS2. tjsError.h contains declarations for TJS C++ exceptions.
The locale is specified by setlocale. If the locale is not specified, the "C" locale will result, and conversion between Japanese narrow and wide characters will not work.
The TJS2 script engine is created with the new operator.
It is in a try block. TJS2 errors are signaled by exceptions, so care must be taken in exception handling.
Declares a tTJSVariant type variable to receive the result of executing the script.

Script is executed using tTJS::ExecScript. Specify the script to be executed as the first argument. String literals are converted to wide strings using the TJS_W macro to pass in the tjs_char * type. The script defines a function test and returns the result of calling that function. In this example, the result of the execution is returned by the return statement, and it is received in the result variable. If it is not necessary to receive the result, neither the return statement nor the second argument of tTJS::ExecScript is required (in that case, 2 The second argument is NULL). The third argument of tTJS::ExecScript is the execution context, but specify NULL here. If NULL is specified, the script will be executed in the global context. The fourth argument of tTJS::ExecScript specifies the name of this script. If NULL, it is treated as anonymous. The name must be human readable.
Showing results. Here, tTJSVariant is cast to int type.
An eTJSError type exception has been received.

eTJSError::GetMessage is used to display the reason for the exception. We use tTJSString::c_str to convert the message to const tjs_char *. Since tjs_char is a wide character, printf specifies %ls as the conversion specifier.
Releasing TJS2 script engine. Prior to release, the TJS2 script engine is shut down using tTJS::Shutdown.

doc.para:
Calling TJS2 function In this method, the function declared on the TJS2 side is called from C++. Let's write in the above try block as follows.
tTJSVariant result; // Variable to receive the result
tjsengine->ExecScript(
TJS_W("function test(x, y) { return x*y; }"), NULL, NULL, TJS_W("test"));
tjsengine->EvalExpression(TJS_W("test(4, 5)"), &result, NULL, NULL);
// Execute expression using tTJS::EvalExpression
printf("Result: %d\n", (int)result); // Show results
iTJSDispatch2 * global = tjsengine->GetGlobalNoAddRef();
// Get global object
tTJSVariant param[] = { 4, 5 }; // Variables passed as parameters
tTJSVariant *p_param[] = { param + 0, param + 1 }; // Array of pointers to variables
TJS_THROW_IF_ERROR(global->FuncCall(0, TJS_W("test"), NULL, &result, 2, p_param, NULL));
// Call test as a function
printf("Result: %d\n", (int)result); // Show results
Lines 3 through 4
Declares function test. test is registered to global.
Line 6
An expression is executed using tTJS::EvalExpression. If you don't need to be very fast, it's easy to pass the expression as a string and receive the result. By the way, for simple expressions (such as those that do not include other execution units, such as function declarations), the compilation results are cached to some extent, and the second and subsequent expressions can be evaluated at high speed.
Line 11
Getting global object. The difference between tTJS::GetGlobal and tTJS::GetGlobalNoAddRef is that the former increments the reference counter of the global object, while the latter does not. Incrementing the reference counter and decrementing when you are done with it means locking the object in the meantime so that it does not disappear. If you do not have to worry about the global object disappearing like this example, you do not need to manipulate the reference counter, so you can use tTJS::GetGlobalNoAddRef. In this case, you do not need a Release when you have finished using it.
Lines 14 through 15
Preparing parameters to pass to the function. This preparation is necessary because iTJSDispatch :: FuncCall requires an array of tTJSVariant pointers as parameters to be passed to the function.
Line 17
Function "test" is called using iTJSDispatch2::FuncCall. The last argument of FuncCall is this (execution context) passed to the function test, but NULL can be specified because this is not used in the test declared in this example. If there is a context to execute, you must specify that object. TJS_THROW_IF_ERROR is a macro that raises an exception with the corresponding error message when the result of tjs_error type is an error.

Native functions You can create native implementations (functions implemented in C++ etc.) and access them from the TJS2 side. You can call functions written in any language that can implement iTJSDispatch2 without using C++, but C++ is the easiest.
When writing a function in C++, it is easy to derive a class from tTJSNativeFunction (described in tjsNative.h). (However, it is possible to operate as a function just by implementing FuncCall of iTJSDispatch2.)
Let's implement a simple function that multiplies two given arguments and returns them.
class TestFunc : public tTJSNativeFunction
{
public:
tjs_error Process(tTJSVariant *result, tjs_int numparams,
tTJSVariant **param, iTJSDispatch2 *objthis)
{
if(numparams < 2) return TJS_E_BADPARAMCOUNT; // Not enough arguments
if(!result) return TJS_S_OK; // Return if no need to store result
*result = *param[0] * *param[1]; // Calculation
return TJS_S_OK; // Returns TJS_S_OK to indicate success
}
};
The only method that should be implemented in a class that inherits tTJSNativeFunction is the Process method as described above. The arguments of the Process method are as follows.
tTJSVariant *result
A pointer to a variable of type tTJSVariant for storing the result of the function is passed. Note that NULL is passed if the caller does not need the result.
tjs_int numparams
Number of arguments passed to the function.
tTJSVariant **param
An array of pointers to tTJSVariant variables that contain the arguments passed to the function.
iTJSDispatch2 *objthis
The context in which the function should be executed. If you are implementing a context-independent implementation, you can ignore it.
To make a native function accessible from TJS2, it must be registered with an object accessible from within TJS2. In the following example, it is registered as "test" in global. Also, it actually calls that function.
iTJSDispatch2 * global = tjsengine->GetGlobalNoAddRef();
// Get global object
iTJSDispatch2 *func = new TestFunc(); // Create TestFunc object
tTJSVariant func_var(func); // Set object to tTJSVariant type func_var
func->Release(); // Release func
TJS_THROW_IF_ERROR(
global->PropSet(TJS_MEMBERENSURE, TJS_W("test"), NULL, &func_var, NULL));
// Register
tTJSVariant result; // Variable to receive the result
tjsengine->EvalExpression(TJS_W("test(4, 5)"), &result, NULL, NULL);
// Execute expression using tTJS::EvalExpression
printf("Result: %d\n", (int)result); // Show results
Lines 4 through 6
Creates an object of class TestFunc that implements native functions and converts it to tTJSVariant type. In line 5, the function is converted to tTJSVariant type. At this point, since the tTJSVariant type automatically manages the reference counter of the function object, the function object is released in line 6.
Lines 8 through 9
The function is registered as "test" in the global object. It calls the global object iTJSDispatch2::PropSet with the TJS_MEMBERENSURE flag to create a new member.
Lines 12 through 16
Calls the function and displays the result.
